title: Light waves, visible and invisible

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary limitation of the human eye when it comes to perceiving light?

options.label: A
options.text: The eye can only see in black and white.

options.label: B
options.text: The eye can only see a small part of the full spectrum of light.

options.label: C
options.text: The eye can see all types of electromagnetic radiation.

options.label: D
options.text: The eye can see in infrared light.

multiple-choice.question: What is the nature of light according to the principles of physics?

options.label: C
options.text: Light is both a wave and a particle.

options.label: D
options.text: Light is neither a wave nor a particle.

multiple-choice.question: What determines the interaction of light with matter?
What is the range of energy that the human eye can detect?
What is the rainbow we see actually composed of?

options.label: C
options.text: Visible light in order of its energy.

multiple-choice.question: What makes one kind of light different from another?
What can be built to measure light outside of the visible range?

options.label: A
options.text: The light of distant stars and galaxies.

options.label: B
options.text: The light of nearby stars and galaxies.

options.label: C
options.text: The light of the moon and the sun.

options.label: D
options.text: The light of the Earth's atmosphere.

multiple-choice.question: How can we apply our knowledge of the physics of light to study the universe?

options.label: B
options.text: By studying the light of distant stars and galaxies.

options.label: C
options.text: By applying our knowledge of the energy of light.

options.label: D
options.text: By studying the light of nearby stars and galaxies.

multiple-choice.question: What can knowing a little bit about the natural world help us do?

options.label: A
options.text: Perceive the full spectrum of light.

options.label: B
options.text: See beyond what our eyes can and can't see.

options.label: C
options.text: Study the light of distant stars and galaxies.

title: Origins of religion

multiple-choice.question: What was the Stone Age people's understanding of the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: A large, spherical universe with many galaxies

options.label: B
options.text: A flat, small, and under-sky universe

options.label: C
options.text: A universe with a single, central sun

options.label: D
options.text: A universe with no stars or planets

multiple-choice.question: What did the Stone Age people believe was the source of movement in the natural world?

options.label: B
options.text: The will of spirits and gods

multiple-choice.question: What did the Stone Age people believe was the purpose of preserving a corpse?

options.label: B
options.text: To help preserve the spirit of the deceased

options.label: C
options.text: To honor the memory of the deceased

options.label: D
options.text: To use the body parts for magic and rituals

multiple-choice.question: What did the Stone Age people believe was the source of natural phenomena such as lightning and thunder?
How did the Stone Age people understand the concept of spirits and materiality?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed that spirits and materiality were separate and distinct

options.label: B
options.text: They believed that spirits and materiality were intertwined and inseparable

options.label: C
options.text: They believed that spirits were the cause of all material phenomena

options.label: D
options.text: They believed that materiality was the cause of all spiritual phenomena

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of storytelling in the Stone Age people's culture?

options.label: A
options.text: To pass down historical events and facts

options.label: B
options.text: To describe their world in a way that they could understand

multiple-choice.question: What did the Stone Age people believe was the source of their imagination and creativity?

options.label: B
options.text: Painting a face on the belly of a pregnant woman in hope of encouraging birth

multiple-choice.question: What did the Stone Age people believe was the purpose of their worldview?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand and explain the natural world

options.label: B
options.text: To provide a sense of social progress and image of humanity's capabilities

options.label: C
options.text: To pass down their cultural and social values

multiple-choice.question: What would have happened if the Stone Age people had had a more developed sense of imagination and capabilities?

options.label: A
options.text: Modern society would have appeared much sooner

options.label: B
options.text: They would have remained in their current state of development

options.label: C
options.text: They would have regressed to a more primitive state

options.label: D
options.text: They would have remained the same but with more technology
